articles.headline: A Pattern of Lavish Spending at a Leading L.G.B.T.Q. Nonprofit
articles.snippet: GLAAD paid for its chief executive to fly first-class, rent a Cape Cod house and remodel her home office. It may have violated I.R.S. rules.
articles.abstract: GLAAD paid for its chief executive to fly first-class, rent a Cape Cod house and remodel her home office. It may have violated I.R.S. rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: A light rain fell at the Zurich airport one Sunday morning in January 2023 as Sarah Kate Ellis made her way from a seat in Delta’s most exclusive cabin to a waiting Mercedes. It was there to chauffeur her to the Swiss Alps, where she and her colleagues would stay at the Tivoli Lodge, a seven-bedroom chalet that cost nearly half a million dollars to rent for the week.

articles.headline: Trump Elevates False, Fringe Attacks on Harris to Center of His Campaign
articles.snippet: Rivals and critics have for years accused Kamala Harris of shifting her personal identity for political advantage, with those attacks escalating dramatically online since she became the Democratic standard-bearer.
articles.abstract: Rivals and critics have for years accused Kamala Harris of shifting her personal identity for political advantage, with those attacks escalating dramatically online since she became the Democratic standard-bearer.
articles.lead_paragraph: When former President Donald J. Trump questioned Vice President Kamala Harris’s racial identity on Wednesday, he lifted a longstanding and false line of attack from the fringes of political discourse to the very center of a presidential campaign.

articles.headline: Major Inmate Swap Frees Dissidents and U.S. Journalists From Russian Prisons
articles.snippet: The Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich was among 24 people released in a seven-nation, painstakingly negotiated deal that President Biden hailed as a triumph of diplomacy.
articles.abstract: The Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich was among 24 people released in a seven-nation, painstakingly negotiated deal that President Biden hailed as a triumph of diplomacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: A prisoner swap on Thursday among seven countries freed the Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich and two other Americans held in Russia, along with several jailed Russian dissidents, in a deal whose size and complexity has no parallel in the post-Soviet era.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Harris Begins Final Phase of Accelerated V.P. Search
articles.snippet: The formal vetting process is finished, and the first major decision of Vice President Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign is just days away.
articles.abstract: The formal vetting process is finished, and the first major decision of Vice President Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign is just days away.
articles.lead_paragraph: The law firm hired by the Harris campaign to investigate potential vice-presidential candidates has completed its work, leaving the final decision — the most important yet of the still-new campaign — squarely in Vice President Kamala Harris’s hands.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer, Reid J. Epstein and Katie Glueck

articles.headline: Behind the Prisoner Swap: Spies, a Killer, Secret Messages and Unseen Diplomacy
articles.snippet: The negotiations that led to the prisoner swap and the freeing of Americans wrongfully held in Russia required patience and creativity, but gave both sides what they wanted most.
articles.abstract: The negotiations that led to the prisoner swap and the freeing of Americans wrongfully held in Russia required patience and creativity, but gave both sides what they wanted most.
articles.lead_paragraph: A turning point came on June 25, when a group of C.I.A. officers sat across from their Russian counterparts during a secret meeting in a Middle Eastern capital.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Anton Troianovski, Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker

articles.headline: In Xi’s China, Politics Eventually Catches Up With Everyone
articles.snippet: The author Peter Hessler posed a question with an elusive answer: How could Chinese society open up so profoundly while its politics stagnated or even regressed?
articles.abstract: The author Peter Hessler posed a question with an elusive answer: How could Chinese society open up so profoundly while its politics stagnated or even regressed?
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1996, when Peter Hessler taught at a small college in Sichuan Province, 90 percent of his students came from villages. Mr. Hessler, 5 feet 9 inches, towered over them by about half a head. They often had just one outfit to wear: a blue suit jacket, or maybe a knockoff Chicago Bulls jersey. One student told him decades later that he could afford only one meal a day.

articles.headline: Washington Post C.E.O.’s Last Company Lost Millions Betting on Gen Z
articles.snippet: The  Post is creating a division under Will Lewis, its C.E.O., to find valuable audiences in new places. His last company shows that’s a tough road.
articles.abstract: The  Post is creating a division under Will Lewis, its C.E.O., to find valuable audiences in new places. His last company shows that’s a tough road.
articles.lead_paragraph: In late 2020, a news start-up began pitching investors on a bold vision: By creating content native to social media for Gen Z audiences — and later acquiring brands like The Daily Mail — the company would begin to create “the Amazon of News” within five years.
articles.byline: By Benjamin Mullin, Katie Robertson and Justin Scheck

articles.headline: Trump Cites Opportunity Zones as a Triumph. Their Success Is Middling.
articles.snippet: A tax incentive, with bipartisan roots, aims to foster development in poor areas. It has fueled building, but it hasn’t always aided local residents.
articles.abstract: A tax incentive, with bipartisan roots, aims to foster development in poor areas. It has fueled building, but it hasn’t always aided local residents.
articles.lead_paragraph: On an Alabama day so oppressive that the sweat pools on your face in the shade, Alex Flachsbart talks almost too rapidly to understand and drives around central Birmingham with similar velocity. Every few minutes, he pulls over to expound on a victory: neglected public housing, a long-empty factory, a crumbling department store, all being transformed into shiny apartments or airy office and retail space.

articles.headline: Kids at the Olympics: ‘It’s Honestly Kind of Insane.’
articles.snippet: From the shooting range to the swimming pool, teens and preteens are grabbing medals and the spotlight. Nowhere is this truer than at the skateboard park.
articles.abstract: From the shooting range to the swimming pool, teens and preteens are grabbing medals and the spotlight. Nowhere is this truer than at the skateboard park.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a hot Sunday morning, and the women’s street skateboarding venue at the Place de la Concorde was swarming with teens.

articles.headline: Is the Fed Behind the Curve? As Unemployment Rises, Worries Mount.
articles.snippet: Central bankers are preparing to cut interest rates, and are monitoring job data as they consider when and how much to lower them.
articles.abstract: Central bankers are preparing to cut interest rates, and are monitoring job data as they consider when and how much to lower them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials held off on cutting interest rates this week because they wanted to see slightly more data to feel confident that inflation is truly coming under control. While that approach is cautious when it comes to price increases, Friday’s employment report underscored that it might be a risky one when it comes to the job market.

articles.headline: A One-Man Team’s 11-Second Olympics
articles.snippet: Winzar Kakiouea, a 100-meter runner, is the only competitor at the Paris Games from the Pacific island nation of Nauru. His debut came and went in a flash.
articles.abstract: Winzar Kakiouea, a 100-meter runner, is the only competitor at the Paris Games from the Pacific island nation of Nauru. His debut came and went in a flash.
articles.lead_paragraph: As his nation’s lone athlete at the Paris Olympics, Winzar Kakiouea carried an additional burden: Most people have no idea that his country is a country.

articles.headline: Olympic Officials Defend Fighters’ Eligibility in Women’s Boxing Controversy
articles.snippet: Online fury and unclear rules have left organizers of the women’s boxing competition in Paris facing complex questions about fairness in women’s sports.
articles.abstract: Online fury and unclear rules have left organizers of the women’s boxing competition in Paris facing complex questions about fairness in women’s sports.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lin Yu-ting strode toward the boxing ring on Friday fully aware that she was walking straight into a swirling controversy that has turned the Paris Olympics into a forum for a fierce debate about biology, gender and fairness in women’s sports.
articles.byline: By Jeré Longman and Emmanuel Morgan
